name: Writing and Reading Ça Va – Quiz 1
description: Practice basic French greetings and introductions through writing and reading exercises.

questions.question: How do you say
? (informal)
questions.explanation: Ça va ? is a greeting and almost never a real question. Briefly respond with ça va or bien to acquaintances, and be more open with friends.

questions.question: How do you say "excuse-me"? (formal)
questions.explanation: Excusez-moi is a versatile phrase that can be used in a variety of situations to express politeness, to apologize, or to get someone's attention.

questions.question: How do you say
? (formal)
questions.explanation: It is a formal way to ask "how are you?

questions.question: How do you say
? (informal)
questions.explanation: When it's informal, your first name is enough. When it's formal, your full name with first name and last name is better. French people don't say their middle names in this context.

questions.question: How do you say
? (feminine)
questions.explanation: When it's an adjective about your nationality or the language, you don't capitalize. Only capitalize when you talk about the country or the nationality as a name.

questions.question: How do you say
questions.explanation: All options can be used to express feeling well or not well, depending on the context.

questions.question: How do you say "nice to meet you"? (informal)
options: B. C'était bien de te rencontrer
C. C'était sympa de te rencontrer.
questions.correctAnswer: C. C'était sympa de te rencontrer.
questions.explanation: It is grammatically correct but it usually does not sound very natural in French. Plus it needs to occur after a first real conversation. Otherwise, it might sound fake to French people.

questions.question: How do you say "I'm practising my French"?(informal)
options: B. Je m'entraîne à parler français.
C. Je m'exerce à parler français.
questions.explanation: Practice means pratiquer but it's more used for playing sport rather than speaking a foreign language. If you say Je pratique mon français, people will understand but it won't sound very natural. It's better to say : je m'exerce à parler français or je m'entraîne à parler français.

questions.question: How do you gesture "hello"? (informal and casual)
questions.explanation: French people hardly ever hug each other. The equivalent is to kiss on the cheeks lightly. Two kisses, one on each cheek, is the standard in Paris. The more south you go, the more kisses you do (maximum 4).

questions.question: How do you say "I miss my family"?
questions.explanation: is never translated by Je manque. You always have this reflexive verb construction with me manquer (literally translates to "to be missing to me"). Another example : I miss my friends/Mes amis me manquent.
